data.note: Generation, transmission and distribution are independent in Argentina under the law 24.065. Among utilities, Pampa Holding is a vertically-integrated company, acting in the three sectors; Endesa acts in the generation sector and owns Edesur; AES acts in the generation sector and owns Edelap. However, no utility monopolises the country's power market.
data.name: The power sector has been unbundled (whether privatized or not) into distinct actors for generation, transmission, distribution and retail

data.note: There are private companies and government-owned companies in each segment.
data.name: There are legally separate private companies at each segment of the power system pre-retail

data.note: Cammesa operates the technical dispatch -- it is a company with private management but a public mandate. ENRE regulates the concessions under which transmission operations occur.
data.name: There is an independent transmission system that dispatches according to market dynamics and is not susceptible to state interference

data.note: In the past 13 years, subsidising electricity prices has cost the government as much as $51bn. However, Argentina's new president,  who has been in power since December 2015, aims to eliminate subsidies and raise electricity bills. Higher electricity tariffs are in force since February 2016.
data.name: Retail electricity prices aren't distorted by subsidies

data.note: There are indirect barriers to private sector participation in the generation sector, such as imported fuel subsidies, an exchange rate crisis and high rates of inflation. Despite this, 75% of installed capacity is private and there is no impediment for a generator to sign a bilateral PPA or enter in the Mercado Electrico Mayorista in Argentina.
data.name: There aren't significant barriers to private sector participation in generation

data.note: Consumers cannot choose retail suppliers or enter into a third-party power market.
data.name: Consumers can choose retail suppliers or third-party power marketers in the retail power market

data.note: The wholesale market is not functioning, according to Cammesa.
data.name: There is a functioning competitive wholesale generation market

data.note: There are several different generators, both public and private. Private generators account for 75% of the installed capacity.
data.name: The generation market has many different actors and is not concentrated in the hands of a few players

data.note: Argentina has 23 provinces, each of which has its own distribution utility. Edenor, Edesur and Edelap are the three main distributors in Argentina covering 75% of the Buenos Aires area.
data.name: The supply market has many different actors and is not concentrated in the hands of a few players
